title: RS22482
content: President Bush signed the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 into law on July 30, 2002. This law is considered significant securities legislation following the Enron and WorldCom scandals. It established the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board and imposed restrictions on accounting firms providing services to companies they audit. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 imposed restrictions on accounting firms providing services to companies they audit and required new disclosures for public companies. It also addressed issues such as securities fraud, penalties for violating securities laws, insider trading blackouts, and protections for corporate whistleblowers. Section 404, Management Assessment of Internal Controls, is a controversial provision of the act. Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act requires companies to maintain internal control structures for financial reporting and assess their effectiveness. Registered public accounting firms must attest to and report on the management's assessment. This provision has faced criticism for being burdensome and costly for small and medium-sized companies. Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, criticized for being burdensome and costly for small and medium-sized companies, has faced opposition due to extreme costs. The SEC has taken steps to delay compliance for small companies, but ultimately all public companies will be required to comply with internal control reporting requirements. The SEC adopted rule changes on December 15, 2006, giving smaller firms more time to comply with Section 404's internal controls reporting requirements. Non-accelerated filers must provide management's assessment in annual reports for fiscal years ending on or after December 15, 2007. The SEC endorsed recommendations to issue auditing standards to ease the burden on small companies in complying with Section 404. The SEC adopted rule changes in December 2006 to give smaller firms more time to comply with Section 404's internal controls reporting requirements. On May 23, 2007, SEC commissioners approved relaxed guidelines for smaller public companies regarding internal accounting controls under Section 404. Bills introduced in Congress aimed to address compliance issues faced by small and medium-sized companies with Section 404 reporting requirements. The bills introduced in Congress aimed to address compliance issues faced by small and medium-sized companies with Section 404 reporting requirements, setting de minimus standards and requiring a study on implementing the principles-based Turnbull Guidance. Bills introduced in the 110th Congress aimed to address compliance issues with Section 404 reporting requirements. H.R. 1049, titled the Amend Misinterpreted Excessive Regulation in Corporate America Act (AMERICA), proposed creating an ombudsman for the PCAOB to assist with audit report disputes and confidentiality issues. The bill introduced in the 110th Congress aimed to address compliance issues with Section 404 reporting requirements by requiring the SEC and PCAOB to adopt revisions to their rules. It also aimed to prohibit private right of action against registered public accounting firms for violations of Section 404. The bills introduced in the 109th Congress aimed to amend Section 404, requiring public accounting firms to attest to and report on management assessments of issuers every three years. The SEC would develop materiality standards for these assessments, focusing on internal controls affecting financial statements and the issuer's financial status. The bills introduced in the 109th Congress aimed to amend Section 404, requiring public accounting firms to attest to and report on management assessments of issuers every three years. The bills would have permitted smaller public companies to be exempt from Section 404 if they met certain criteria. Additionally, the SEC and the Board would have been required to conduct studies on competition for audit performance and compare principles-based guidance from Great Britain to Section 404 of Sarbanes-Oxley. Several other bills affecting compliance with Section 404 were introduced in subsequent Congresses. In the 110th and 111th Congress, bills were introduced to provide exemptions for small companies from Section 404 requirements. H.R. 3817, the Investor Protection Act, included a clause exempting businesses with a market capitalization up to $75 million from auditing requirements. The SEC would study ways to reduce compliance burden for companies valued between $75 million and $250 million. This bill was included in the Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2009. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2009, passed by the House in December 2009, included a provision exempting businesses with a market capitalization of $75 million or less from auditing requirements. The SEC was tasked with finding ways to reduce compliance burden for companies valued between $75 million and $250 million. The bill was signed into law as P.L. 111-203 on July 21, 2010. The Jumpstart Our Business Startups Act (JOBS Act) was passed in response to bills introduced in the 112th Congress, allowing certain companies with over $75 million in capital to be exempt from certain provisions of federal securities laws. Section 103 of the JOBS Act exempts emerging growth companies with less than $1 billion in annual revenue from auditing requirements for up to five years. The bill was signed into law on April 5, 2012.
